Award.AwardTitle: Complexity of Simulating Quantum Adiabatic Optimization by Quantum Monte Carlo Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project "Complexity of Simulating Quantum Adiabatic Optimization by Quantum Monte Carlo Methods" investigates the computational power and weaknesses of a widely used method for simulating quantum physics. The Quantum Monte Carlo method is a commonly used algorithm for analyzing and simulating large, coherent quantum systems. Although it is known that this method can not efficiently simulate all quantum mechanical systems, it is also known to provide reliable answers for a large subclass of such systems. The project focuses on the specific question whether or not a quantum computer running the Quantum Adiabatic Optimization algorithm is efficiently simulatable by the Quantum Monte Carlo method.Â 

The theory of quantum computation looks at the question which problems can be solved efficiently on a quantum computer that do not have an efficient solution using classical computation. An important case of this theory concerns Quantum Adiabatic Optimization, which is a general purpose quantum algorithm that attempts to find the optimal value in an exponentially large landscape of function values. Despite more than 12 years of study, it is still not known to which extend this quantum heuristic performs better than classical heuristics. On the one hand, it is possible that a classical algorithm that uses the Quantum Monte Carlo method will be able to efficiently simulate quantum adiabatic optimization, which would prove a strong limitation on the 'quantum benefit' of the quantum adiabatic approach to solving optimization problems. On the other hand, it is also possible that one can prove that the Quantum Monte Carlo method does not succeed in efficiently mimicking the quantum adiabatic algorithm, thus providing strong evidence that quantum adiabatic optimization does indeed have computational powers that go beyond classical computation. This project aims to determine which one of these two possibilities is the case. Research in quantum computation is high interdisciplinary with impacts in a number of areas of physics and computer science. In addition, this project will support the education and training of a graduate student in this cross-disciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project the Principle Investigator Wim van Dam and his PhD student Lucas Brady investigated the power and limitations of Quantum Adiabatic Optimization and that of classical algorithms that use Quantum Monte Carlo techniques. They clarified how a quantum computer---using quantum adiabatic algorithms and the phenomenon of quantum tunneling---can find the solutions to optimization problems more efficiently than classical local search algorithms can. 

 

More specifically, Van Dam and Brady analyzed how well quantum tunneling succeeds in minimizing one-dimensional cost functions that have a barriers that hide the optimal solution. Such hidden global solutions can be hard to find by traditional local search algorithms, but they can be easier to find by quantum algorithms that can tunnel through these barriers, provided the barriers are not too big. As part of this project the principal investigator and his student determined the relationship between the size of the barriers and the sufficient running time of the quantum adiabatic algorithm that tunnels through that barrier. This analysis resolved a conjecture on polynomially efficient tunneling that was open since 2002. These and related results by Van Dam and Brady have been published in several refereed journal articles. 

 

A second part of the project concerned the analysis of quantum Monte Carlo algorithms, which is a technique for simulating quantum physics on a classical computer. Van Dam and Brady showed that the above described one-dimensional tunneling can typically be simulated  efficiently using quantum Monte Carlo techniques. While classical local search algorithm can not tunnel efficiently; quantum Monte Carlo implements a non-local approach to solving minimization problems, which allows It to overcome the barriers in the cost function. This result by Van Dam and Brady has independently been confirmed by other research groups and it tells us that for quantum algorithms to achieve a significant advantage over classical algorithms, the quantum computer will have to use phenomena that go beyond one-dimensional tunneling.
